The '''Vati-Con Scandal''' involved accusations that Italian real estate developer Raffaello Follieri misappropriated a $50 million investment<ref>[http://www.nypost.com/pagesixmag/issues/20080629/Inside+Story+Raffaello+Follieri "Inside Story: Raffaello Follieri"] (June 29, 2008) ''[[New York Post]]''</ref> from [[Bill Clinton]] and billionaire [[Ronald Burkle]] meant to buy [[Roman Catholic]] churches in the [[United States]].<ref>[http://natcath.org/NCR_Online/archives2/2006a/030306/030306a.php "Catholic real estate bonanza"] (March 3, 2006) ''[[National Catholic Reporter]]''</ref> Follieri ultimately pleaded guilty to federal criminal charges in the U.S. and was sentenced to prison.
On July 15, 2008, Bishop [[Joseph Anthony Galante]] of the [[Diocese of Camden]], [[New Jersey]], was implicated in the scandal by a ''[[New York Post]]'' article titled "A Deal with the Devil" that revealed that Follieri had bought Galante's beach house for $400,000 in 2007 shortly after Galante began the study that resulted in his 2008 announcement to sell off half of the Diocese's church properties.<ref>[http://www.nypost.com/seven/07152008/news/regionalnews/a_deal_with_the_devil_119940.htm "A Deal with the Devil"] (July 18, 2008) ''[[New York Post]]''</ref> Following disclosure of the bishop's involvement in Vati-Con, the Council of Parishes of Southern New Jersey demanded "a complete halt to the Bishop’s planned church closure program".{{Citation needed|date=January 2013}} The Galante/Follieri beach house was put back on the market in 2008 and sold almost two years later for $310,000.<ref>[http://www.zillow.com/homedetails/749-W-Oak-Ave-North-Wildwood-NJ-08260/38359482_zpid/ Zillow.com 749 W Oak Ave., North Wildwood NJ].</ref>
On July 24, 2008, the ''[[Daily News (New York)|New York Daily News]]'' reported that during a second raid of Follieri's apartment in New York City, the [[Federal Bureau of Investigation|FBI]] had confiscated the private journals of Follieri's former girlfriend, American film actress [[Anne Hathaway]], as part of their ongoing investigation into the scandal. Hathaway did not face any charges related to the scandal.<ref>[http://www.nydailynews.com/gossip/2008/07/24/2008-07-24_fbi_grabs_anne_hathaways_diaries.html "FBI Grabs Anne Hathaway's diaries"] (July 24, 2008) ''NY Daily News''</ref>
In October 2008, Follieri pleaded guilty in [[Manhattan]] to the charges, and [[United States federal judge|Federal Judge]] [[John G. Koeltl|John Koeltl]] imposed a 4½ year prison sentence.<ref>[http://www.accesshollywood.com/anne-hathaways-ex-sentenced-to-54-months-in-prison_article_11841 "Anne Hathaway's Ex Sentenced To 54 Months In Prison"] (Oct. 23, 2008) Access Hollywood</ref> He was released on May 25, 2012, from a federal prison in Pennsylvania. The [[U.S. Department of Homeland Security]]'s [[Immigration and Customs Enforcement]] deported Follieri to [[Italy]] on May 25, 2012, immediately after his release from prison.<ref>[http://www.dailymail.co.uk/tvshowbiz/article-2150251/Anne-Hathaways-ex-uuuuboyfriend-Raffaello-Follieri-deported-America-prison-release.html "Anne Hathaway's ex-boyfriend Raffaello Follieri deported from America after prison release"] ( May 25, 2012) ''Daily Mail''</ref>

{{Use dmy dates|date=October 2015}} {{Use Indian English|date=October 2015}} {{Infobox Christian leader | honorific-prefix = [[Excellency|His Excellency]], [[The Most Reverend]] | name = William Leonard D'Mello | honorific-suffix = | title = [[Roman Catholic Diocese of Karwar|Bishop of Karwar]] | image = | image_size = | caption = Bishop Burbidge at [[St. Raphael the Archangel Catholic Church]] on the [[Feast of the Archangels]] in 2010. | archdiocese = [[Roman Catholic Archdiocese of Bangalore|Bangalore]] | diocese = [[Roman Catholic Diocese of Karwar|Karwar]] | appointed = 24 January 1976 | enthroned = | ended = 24 February 2007 | predecessor = ''Inaugural'' | successor = [[Derek Fernandes]] | ordination = 16 April 1957 | ordained_by = | consecration = 29 April 1977 | consecrated_by = [[Duraisamy Simon Lourdusamy]] | birth_name = William Leonard D'Mello | birth_date = 24 March 1931 | birth_place =[[Mangalore]] | death_date =19 July 2011 | death_place = Mangalore | buried = Cathedral of the Assumption of Our Lady, Kajubag | nationality = [[India]]n | religion = [[Roman Catholic]] | residence = [[Karwar, Karnataka]] | parents = | spouse = | children = | occupation = | previous_post = | profession = | alma_mater = | signature = | coat_of_arms = | motto = ''Duc in Altum'' }} '''William Leonard D'Mello''' (24 March 1931 – 19 July 2011) was the first [[Roman Catholic]] bishop of the [[Roman Catholic Diocese of Karwar]], [[India]].
Born in [[Mangalore]] and ordained to the priesthood in 1957, D'Mello was named bishop of the Karwar Diocese in 1976 and retired in 2007.<ref name="Joyson">{{cite news|url=http://www.catholic-hierarchy.org/bishop/bdmello.html |title=Bishop William Leonard D’Mello|publisher=Catholic-Hierarchy|accessdate=22 July 2011}}</ref>
==Early life== D'Mello was born on March 24, 1931, at Cascia, the third of six children born to Joseph and Santana D'Mello.<ref name="Obit">{{cite web|url=http://m.daijiworld.com/viewNews.aspx?nid=108897|title=Former Bishop of Karwar William D'Mello Passes Away at 82|date=July 2011|work=[[Daijiworld Media]]|accessdate=9 December 2016}}</ref>
==Bishop of Karwar== On January 24, 1976, at 44 years of age, D'Mello was appointed Bishop of the newly-erected Diocese of Karwar by Pope [[Paul VI]]. His episcopal consecration took place only on April 29, 1977. Archbishop [[Duraisamy Simon Lourdusamy]] served as Consecrator, assisted by Archbishop [[Packiam Arokiaswamy]] and Bishop [[Ignatius P. Lobo]].<ref name="Obit"/>
One of D'Mello's key initiatives was promoting vocations to the priesthood and the religious life in his diocese. He encouraged young men to enter the seminary, and sought to bring more congregations of religious sisters into his new diocese.
==Retirement== D'Mello submitted his resignation upon reaching the age of 75 as required by the [[Code of Canon Law]] and in February 2007, [[Pope Benedict XVI]] accepted his resignation and appointed [[Derek Fernandes]] as his successor.
In retirement, he lived at the 'Sandhya Vandan'. D'Mello died July 19, 2011, aged 80 and was buried in the Diocese of Karwar's Cathedral of the Assumption.<ref name="Obit"/>

{{Infobox person | name = Wojciech Michał Lemański | image = Wojciech Lemański.JPG | alt = 250px | caption = | birth_name = | birth_date = {{birth date and age|1960|09|22|df=yes}} | birth_place = [[Legionowo]] | death_date = | death_place = | nationality = Polish | other_names = | known_for = | occupation = priest }} '''Wojciech Michał Lemański''' (born September 22, 1960) is a Roman Catholic Polish priest. He is in conflict with his superior Archbishop [[Henryk Hoser]], who ordered him out of the parish for [[disobedience]] and failing to comply with some of the teachings of the Catholic Church.
First Mgr. Hoser banned Lemański from teaching religious studies in public schools. On July 7, 2013, he asked Lemański to leave the parish and move to a residence for retired priests, despite the fact he was only 52.<ref>[http://vaticaninsider.lastampa.it/en/world-news/detail/articolo/polonia-poland-chiesa-church-iglesia-26463/ Poland: Priest-bishop clash captures nation's attention], Vatican Insider, July 15, 2013</ref> Another option was to be transferred to another parish, where he would serve as an auxiliary staff. Lemański did not agree with the decision and said that he would appeal against it.<ref>[http://www.wbj.pl/article-63310-internal-conflict-in-polish-church-leads-to-a-popular-priest-resigning-from-his-post.html Internal conflict in Polish church leads to a popular priest resigning from his post], Warsaw Business Journal, July 16, 2013</ref> In June 2014 he was made chaplain in an institution for mentally injured children, but two months later he was suspended from the priesthood.
== Critique of the Church == Lemański, ordained in 1987, has repeatedly criticised the church. He has accused the church leadership of not doing enough to oppose anti-Semitic tendencies among Poland's Catholics. Lemański himself is among a few Catholic priests who each year commemorate massacres of Jews at [[Treblinka extermination camp|the Treblinka camp]], where Jews, along with Poles and others, were gassed. He also recovered gravestones from abandoned and destroyed Jewish cemeteries, incorporating two of them into the main altar of his church. Some conservative Catholics said he was turning it into a [[synagogue]].<ref>[http://www.huffingtonpost.com/2013/08/01/poland-catholic-church-jews_n_3688035.html Father Wojciech Lemanski's Dismissal Highlights Catholic Church's Uneasy Relation With Jews In Poland], HuffingtonPost.com, August 1, 2013</ref>
Lemański has also criticized the establishment's lenient treatment of clerics accused of [[sexual abuse]] and its rejection of [[artificial insemination]] and [[contraceptive]]s.
== Suspension == [[Image:2014 Woodstock 109 Wojciech Lemański.jpg|thumb|Wojciech Lemański at the [[Przystanek Woodstock|Woodstock Festival]] 2014]] In July 2013, Lemański was suspended by the archbishop of Warsaw-Praga [[Henryk Hoser]]. On July 14, 2013, when three envoys dispatched by Hoser showed up at Lemanski's church in the town of [[Jasienica, Wołomin County|Jasienica]] near [[Warsaw]], they got surrounded by an angry crowd. The three clerics finally retreated after they were jeered at and booed. They barely managed to get into their car when the crowd began pushing the vehicle in the direction of Warsaw.
Lemański, who originally did not want to budge, later decided to resign, although he still considered the bishops' decision to be unfair. ''"Today you are pushing a car, but tomorrow you will flip it over or possibly even hurt somebody,"'' he told his parishioners. He then left the parsonage saying he will wait for a decision from the Vatican regarding his dispute with the church hierarchy.<ref>[http://www.spiegel.de/international/europe/polish-priest-steps-down-after-clashes-with-catholic-church-a-911688.html Rebel Priest: Church's 'No. 1 Enemy' A Symbol of Polish Change], Spiegel International, July 17, 2013</ref>
A few days later, front-page articles about the case appeared in the [[Newsweek Polska|Polish edition of Newsweek]]<ref>[http://polska.newsweek.pl/ostatnia-msza-w-jasienicy,106590,1,1.html Ostatnia msza w Jasienicy ''(The last mass in Jasienica)''], Newsweek Polska, 3. 8. 2013</ref> and in [[Gazeta Wyborcza]]. At the end of June 2014 archbishop Hoser changed his earlier decision and posted Lemański as a chaplain in an institution for mentally injured children. Lemański continued his activities, also took part in [[Przystanek Woodstock]] music festival. On August 22, 2014, he was suspended from being a priest altogether, the reason being a lack of regret over his deeds in the past and breaking the ban on talking to the media, imposed by the Vatican.<ref>[http://www.tvp.info/16535548/ksiadz-lemanski-suspendowany-arcybiskup-hoser-go-ukaral Ksiądz Lemański bez prawa do sutanny. Abp Hoser go ukarał], TVP info, 22. 8. 2014</ref>
== Awards == In 2008, Lemański received [[Order of Polonia Restituta]] from the hands of former Polish president [[Lech Kaczyński]] for keeping the memory of Polish Jews alive.<ref>[http://swidermajer.nazwa.pl/zo/ksleman.html Ks. Wojciech Lemański wśród kustoszy pamięci odznaczonych przez prezydenta Lecha Kaczyńskiego] (in Polish)</ref> {{Commons category|Wojciech Lemański}} ==References== {{reflist}}
== External links == * [http://www.nataliesmolenski.com/uploads/1/5/4/2/15428708/smolenski_natalie_2014_-_the_father_lemanski_affair.pdf SMOLENSKI, Natalie: The Father Lemański Affair], Journal of Religion in Europe 7 (2014)
